case_vignette: A 50-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of smelling abnormal odors on several occasions. He says that he smells burnt rubber even though there is nothing burning and no one around him can smell what he does. This symptom has been intermittently bothering him for the past 6 months. Also during this period, he had occasional nosebleeds. He works as a high school teacher. Although his work gets a little stressful around the exam season, he says he is able to cope well. Family history is unremarkable. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and denies the use of any medication. Physical examination reveals unilateral nasal obstruction with some dried blood in the nasal passage.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been smelling abnormal odors, like burnt rubber, even when nothing is burning, and no one else seems to smell it. This has been going on for about 6 months.
Have you noticed any seizure activity during these episodes?
No, I haven't noticed any seizure activity.
Final Diagnosis: Phantosmia (Parosmia)

trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is a unilateral olfactory nerve disorder or olfactory dysfunction, also known as "phantosmia" or "parosmia." This condition can present with the perception of unusual odors, such as burnt rubber, in the absence of an external source. Nasal obstruction and intermittent nosebleeds may be secondary findings. Further evaluation, such as an olfactory test or imaging, may be necessary for confirmation.
